fields.summary: As a GH project admin I would like to prevent a user from exceeding a column constraint when dragging issues on the Task Board

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description: We need to edit placement of JIRA issue key on Greenhopper card. We would like to configure the cards so that perforce job #s are in the most prominent position (top left). It would be preferable to be able to hide the issue key on these cards.
fields.summary: Allow changes to placement of JIRA issue key on Greenhopper cards

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description: We really like the increased screen realestate full screen option provides during scrum and sprint planning meetings. However, we need to exit full screen every time we want to switch boards (Planning, Task, Chart). This is due to fact the control to switch boards in is menubar on page. It would be more usable if we could switch between boards without having to leave fullscreen mode.
fields.summary: As a user I can switch boards while in full screen mode.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description: As far as I can tell there is no way to get a reproducible link from GreenHopper for a given page (e.g. a task, planning, or chart board view). This makes it difficult to share links to preconfigured pages with other members of a team. Providing a "bookmarkable link" feature similar to JIRA's issue navigator would solve this problem.
fields.summary: Provide a bookmarkable link for GreenHopper screens

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
If you are, for example, editing a bound on a particular statistic in a version card on the right-hand-side of the version planning board, and you double-click inside of the text edit field to select the entire contents of the field, the entire card collapses.

This makes it difficult to replace the contents of such fields entirely.
fields.summary: Double-clicking collapses a version/component/... card even when clicking inside of an editable field

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description: The iframe functionality in GreenHopper is useful, but unfortunately prevents users from opening links to issues in new tabs (e.g. by middle-clicking in Firefox, Chrome or Safari). Instead of using a javascript: URI as the href attribute for the links, consider using an onclick handler or something similar with a proper URI to the issue as the href to allow "open in new tab" functionality to still work correctly.
fields.summary: iframe links should still work correctly when a user decides to open a link in a new tab

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description: Currently the trendline in a burndown chart is based on the (first and) latest data-point of the series. However, usually this data-point represents a time in the future (end of day today). Thus it makes more sense to base the trendline on the previous day (the second-latest data-point in the series).
fields.summary: Trend lines should (optionally?) start from the previous day

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We upgraded our JIRA test system to 4.01 with GreenHopper 4.2.1. We imported the data from our production system (JIRA 3.13, GreenHopper 3.7.1) using XML import.

On the Planning and Taskboard parent and child issues are now not sorted properly any longer. Parent tasks are on top and child tasks at the bottom (list view).

After consulting the support area we tried the following steps with no success:

(1) Checked sorting, sorted by rank
(2) Optimize/repair ranking field
(3) Restarted JIRA directly after importing
(4) Removed and then added rank for sorting

Any ideas what we might do wrong?
fields.summary: Parent-Child Sorting on Planning and Taskboard

fields.description:
According to [GreenHopper documentation|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GH/Transitioning+Issues+in+GreenHopper]:

bq. Tip: If you want the comment field to always display on transitions, simply set the issue type as a required field on your transition screen.

This does not work in GreenHopper 4.2-jira40

A possible workaround is adding a different required field into the transition screen.
fields.summary: Transition screen does not show even with required fields

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The deprecated GreenHopper FAQ has the following information:

{quote}Which fields are required for GreenHopper to be efficient?

The required fields for GreenHopper to be efficient are:
   1. The fix version and components, otherwise the planning board would not make any sense.
   2. The status of the issue, otherwise the task board would not make any sense.
{quote}

This should be included in the main documentation. In particular, it should emphasise that a custom field cannot be used in place of these fields.
fields.summary: Important information from the deprecated GreenHopper FAQ needs to be included in the main docs

fields.description:
I was editing the iframe status by going Tools > Configuration and then toggling the iframe setting.

I did not realize there was another personal setting through Tools > User Preferences that would then override the Project setting. This functionality makes sense to me now that I think about it, though it might be nice to include a note in the Tools > Configuration explanation of the iframe setting.

I would change it from:

"Use JIRA IFrame: Enables the modal JIRA standard Issue view popup."

to

"Use JIRA IFrame: Enables the modal JIRA standard Issue view popup for the selected project. Note: this setting can be overridden by individual users User Preferences settings for this project."
fields.summary: Clarify the 'Tools > Configuration' iframe setting description

fields.description: When viewing the Task Board in Internet Explorer 8, the "Done" column doesn't display until you mouse over it.  This happens if you have the "compatibility view" enabled, and stops if you turn that view off.  This view can be set per site, and is ticked automatically for the "Local Intranet" security zone, so if you encounter this problem, the workaround is to check those settings and make sure you're not loading the compatibility view for your JIRA instance.

fields.description:
Go to the Planning Board under agile.
Choose List view.
For this particular example, choose project overview. Make sure you have some stories with subtasks. It doesn't really matter which list you look at though - they all display a similar rendering problem.

In Safari 4, the edit button, expand/collapse button, parent link, create subtask button and link to number of subtasks (ie 13 subs) are all obscured or drawn over top of each other. See screenshots, which compare view in firefox 3 to safari 4.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Details on possible integration points, via a customer: 

I have been using for a couple of months now the JIRA plug-in for Eclipse. I really like it, and prefer to use it instead of the JIRA web UI when working on my own tasks.

What I would like to see in an Eclipse plug-in is a way to access:
- the task board based on any filter
- burndown charts (with an option to cache previous charts)
- optionally, the planning board, although this is used only once in a sprint, so it wouldn't be too important

The Greenhopper task board is a much better view of how we're doing in the sprint, while at the moment, I would have to create separate filters to be able to separate activities by their status. 

The burndown charts should be cached locally (mainly by issue and by custom values such as story points); these charts are shown every day, but I see that if I don't have access to the JIRA server, I cannot get the charts. Also, it would be handy if I could keep several chart snapshots in my local Eclipse workspace.

fields.description: Emergent planning is the most powerful feature of PivotalTracker.  If a user specifies the size of stories and the velocity of a team, the system schedules the stories into iterations based simply on the priority of the items in the backlog.  This is powerful because it prevents iterations (and releases) from being overloaded by a person arbitrarily dropping endless stories into an iteration.  It also provides a clear picture of when a feature can be delivered based on current prioritization.  It really opens the process up to product owners.
fields.summary: As a product owner, I want the system to perform emergent planning as I reprioritize the backlog (like PivotalTracker)

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Greenhopper 3.x had the option to click 'refresh' in task board or planning board.  Now the only option is 'auto refresh' which is unusable for most cases since it repaints the entire screen when you least expect it.  Refresh at least let you manually decide when to update the display.  Now we need to refresh the entire browser tab to get it to display which takes much more time than the greenhopper 'refresh' option we loved.  This slows down our meetings.  See attached greenhopper 3.x screenshot

http://skitch.com/cbrookins/np9ds/task-board

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Currently the chartboard "guideline" end points default to the version start & end dates but the end points change (and guideline redrawn) if the start / end dates on the chart are varied.

While a sprint should be timeboxed there are times when it is useful to show that the scheduled sprint end has not been met and the sprint activity continues beyond this scheduled end date.

If the guideline start / end dates were fixed to the version start / end dates then this would permit showing the activity beyond the scheduled date rather than appearing to show the activity always being on time as the dates are  changed on the chartboard
fields.summary: Use (only) version start / end dates for chartboard "guideline" end points

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
This critical feature which we use all of the time when reviewing the task board with our teams was dropped from Greenhopper 4.x.

In our previous Jira 3.x install, stories listed on the greenhopper Task board showed shortcuts for assigning the story to the current user or any other user. Those shortcuts seem to be gone now, so you have to edit the story in Jira to change the asignee which is MUCH slower. Is this a config option we can put back in Greenhopper for Jira 4, or can we get this fixed ASAP in the next greenhopper 4.x release?  This is a big regression from Greenhopper v3.x. See taskboard screenshots below I linked to show the issue.
- In Greenhopper 3.x all is good - http://skitch.com/cbrookins/npqe7/task-board
- In Greenhopper 4.x not so good - http://skitch.com/cbrookins/npqjw/acquia-network-task-board-acquia-backlog

fields.description:
As a developer, I often leave the task board open in a browser tab for a long period of time. In fact, it is always open, but I need to refresh it when I'm wondering if co-workers have made any changes to the state of an issue.

It would be very useful if the task board updated itself periodically. Even better, I'd love if that was near-realtime using COMET (browser keeps a connection to the server).
fields.summary: Update task board when other users make changes

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We are in the process of working towards an upgrade to Jira 4.  We have a few plugins that we have developed that make use of JIRA Agile information when it is available in an installation.  Some examples of the information we access or tasks performed:

# Use of version start dates when available
# Use of master version information when available
# Registration of certain projects with JIRA Agile context on new project creation

In Jira 4, now that the classloaders are segregated with the use of OSGI, it looks like we are having problems accessing the classes we need to make this happen.

As a workaround we have modified the manifest file in the JIRA Agile jar to add the following:

{code}
Export-Package: com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira.configurations,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira.boards.context
{code}

This at least solves our first 2 issues (haven't looked into the 3rd item I mention above yet), as we are now able to access these APIs from our plugin.  I am no OSGI expert, so not sure if Export-Package is the best route, but can the generated plugin artifacts distributed by Atlassian be created in a way where we can access the APIs from our plugins?
fields.summary: Make JIRA Agile APIs available to other plugins

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We choose "Print Chart" in the Chart view. A popup opens and the chart appears as an pnp file in a popup window. We copied out the location of the pnp through properties window, it e.g. says:

http://our.server:8080/jira/charts?filename=jfreechart-onetime-1881258128115079115.png

Copiing this to a browser window results in an error like:

{code}
Cause: 
javax.servlet.ServletException: File 'C:\Program Files\Apache Software Foundation\Tomcat 6.0\temp\jfreechart-onetime-1881258128115079115.png' does not exist 
{code}

It seems that the pnp is temorary saved in Tomcats temp folder, we looked at the server and saw the filename appear for a second in the temp directory, but than it disappears!
A Tomcat issue or what could we do? Appears in Jira 3.13.5 & Jira 4.0.1 Test on Greenhopper 3.8 & 4.2.

Thanks a lot!
fields.summary: Chart does not remain in Tomcat temp path for printing -> Chart can't be printed out

In Greenhopper one resolves an issue by dragging it from the "IN PROGRESS" column to the "DONE" column, but you can't provide any comment so i always have to edit the issue and add the comment myself.

fields.description:
Add a new *view* to the planning board. 
Currently is it: assignee, component, project overview, version.

Customer would like to add a new one: *Filter*

Exact use case as defined below by customer:
{quote}
You can see that the number of sub tasks is shown - but the actual number displayed is not the same. Clicking on the sub tasks link will bring up a child window with ALL the sub tasks shown. We would like the change where ALL subtasks are shown under the parent REGARDLESS of whether the subtask is in a different fix version.

Note what you are seeing above - in our structure we create a version that represents a "project" - the parent issue then represents say a Usecase (eg SUITE-1459), then a substask will be created in workflow with the same fix version as teh parent for a specification/analysis task. When complete the workflow steps then move into creating sub tasks for development/engineering - these sub tasks are then assigned to actual product releases (versions) within Jira/greenhopper. So we are trying to use this planning board view of the Project/version so see at a glance the status of all use cases and what release the development activity is in.
{quote}
fields.summary: I would like to be able to view by a Filter in the planning board.

Seems strange that this section is in the Administration, but it doesn't allow this capability.

fields.description:
At the moment JIRA is the ultimate tool for issue tracking and Agile development. The only thing that is missing (in my opinion) is the ability to work with velocity. I suggested this feature at the Atlassian stand at Devoxx and the man who was listening to my suggestion seemed to agree on the idea. He suggested me to add a feature request in JIRA which is the cause of this issue.

GreenHopper has build in functionality for Story Points. Velocity integration in GreenHopper would be the final feature to make JIRA complete for Agile development. Let me explain how I see a possible implementation of working with velocity. This is only my vision and improvements to this possible implementation are always welcome. My possible implementation will reflect the way of working at my company, but I think that it is applicable to all Agile companies. Please note that screenshots given here are mockups, so no implementation exists at the moment. The mockups are given in a hope to making my proposition clearer.

Every version in JIRA represents a sprint. Each sprint is linked to a certain velocity for that sprint. A possible implementation can be found in screenshot 1. Let me explain.
When the first version (or sprint) is created, there is no velocity yet. The (estimated) price for the project is calculated on a chosen velocity, based on previous experience. Therefore, it is possible to specify a velocity in the textbox.
However, when following sprints are created, the velocity can be calculated using the hours worked and the amount of story points that are resolved. So when a new version is created (sprint 2), you will select sprint 1 as the "Schedule" version in JIRA. When selecting the checkbox next to the velocity textbox, it will discard any input into that textbox and it will calculate the velocity of the previous sprint and use that velocity as the velocity for the newly created version. It is always possible to override the calculated velocity by unchecking the checkbox and entering a custom value.
An extra possible admin feature would be the possibility to adjust the formula used for calculating the velocity based on the previous ("scheduled") version. This could be done by introducing placeholders in the formula textfield like {story.points}, {worked.time}, ... For example, in our company we use the formula {worked.time} / {resolved.story.points}. It would also be nice to be able to select the types of issues that need to be used to calculate the velocity. For example, only issues of the type "Story" are used in the calculations. Issues of the type "Bug" or "New Feature" are not used.

The velocity implemented above, must be visible throughout the application. So not only in the administration module of JIRA, but also in version overviews, etc. Screenshots 2 to 5 are simple, possible examples.
Also a chart that shows the progress/course of the velocity would be a must-have feature. It would show the progress of the team very well.

The only thing that still has to be done, is integrating the use of the velocity into the issues. At our company, the velocity is used to calculate the estimated time for a story. There are 2 possible ways for implementing this:
	# The first possible solution can be seen in screenshot 6. A checkbox is available next to the story points field. When checked, JIRA will calculate the "Original Estimate" using the velocity for the specified version and will bind this value to the "Original estimate" field. Any input into that field will be discarded. This calculation will happen every time the issue is copied/moved to another version. If the story is unscheduled, no calculation will be executed and the estimate will stay empty. Once the issue is resolved, the value will not change anymore. In the screenshot you can see that the story has 1.5 points assigned to it. If the Velocity for the given version is 2, then the original estimate will be 3 days. [Note: also here, it would be a possible admin feature to be able to adjust the formula like described above]
	# The second possible solution can be seen in screenshot 7. Instead of using the "Original estimate" field, an extra field is introduced: "Calculated estimate". Everything else remains the same as in the first solution. The "Calculated estimate" field is a disabled field, which means that no user input is allowed.


I hope that some of the people at Atlassian are eager to implement this feature in this or any other suggested way. Anyways, I already appreciate it if anyone took the time to read this long text.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Working with Velocity in JIRA Software

fields.description:
Many of our users have complained that it is very confusing when the close a story yet there is still remaining effort aggregated from story sub-tasks.

When a user drags story to done column in Task Board the story is closed but any open sub-tasks remain open. This is confusing.

I see two options to address this issue:

1) User should be prompted to transition subtask(s) to done when parent story is dragged to done column. This is similar to popup dialog when re-scheduling story with subtasks in Planning Board. This would alert user that there is still uncompleted tasks and also optionally allow them to quickly close sub-tasks if they are indeed done. They could also choose to cancel the transistion of story if they did not realize there was still undone work items (subtasks).

2) Customize JIRA workflow to block story transition to resolved/closed if it has unresolved child sub-tasks. I think option 1 is better and more user friendly.
fields.summary: A user should be prompted to resolve/close sub-tasks when story is resolved/closed.
